Chapter 10.2: The Price of Lodging
'You have done more than I asked, [placeholder]. I am proud to call you my kin.'
Defeat Orcs in the Beorning-lands ([placeholder]/[placeholder])

'I will allow you to stay, for I know the dangers that lie beyond my walls and I will not make you face them alone. But I do not give you this lodging for free. It will cost you nothing in coin; rather, the price will be the sweat of your brow. Many are the tasks that need doing, and in return for a safe place to stay you will see them done. Do you agree?

'Very good. The road through my lands has become choked in some places with brush. Clear four patches of brush, and you will have made a start on opening the way. We always have need of flint and firewood. Gather four suitable logs and search patches of soil until you find three pieces of flint. Orcs and wargs have been troubling my family ever since my sire came down from the mountains. Slay four Orcs and three wargs, and let them know that these lands are not safe for them!

'That will be a start, [placeholder]. That is my price. Speak to Gandalf and learn if he appreciates this favour!'
Defeat wargs in the Beorning-lands ([placeholder]/[placeholder])

'Grimbeorn has let us off lightly, [placeholder]. Four patches of brush and logs for firewood? Three pieces of flint? And this is not to mention the paltry number of Orcs and wargs he asked that you slay in the fields and meads around his home.

'Grimbeorn, like his sire before him, does not appreciate surprises. Oh, he will warm up to them, in time, but at the outset he looks upon any unexpected arrival with disapproval. You will need to trust me, [placeholder]: if Grimbeorn asks that you clear four patches of brush, you should instead clear eight! If he asks for three pieces of flint, I suggest that you bring him six! In point of fact, I think you should double the quantities of every task he set before you!

'Why? Let us just say that it is important for us to be on the good side of the Beorninghús's master. You will thank me for it, when all is said and done.'

'Why? Is this the Wizard's doing? Why would you do more than I asked? What are you trying to prove, [placeholder]?'

'Very good. The road through our lands has become choked in some places with brush. Clear four patches of brush, and you will have made a start on opening the way. As you well know, Orcs and wargs have been troubling our family ever since my sire came down from the mountains. Slay four Orcs and three wargs, and let them know that these lands are not safe for them!
